channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Protesters Confront Mainland Shoppers in Hong Kong
item.description: The police arrested about a dozen people and used pepper spray to subdue hundreds of protesters who had gathered in a mall to accost shoppers from across the border.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN WONG and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: The Hong Kong police confronting demonstrators protesting on Sunday against an influx of visitors from mainland China.

item.title: Towers of Secrecy: Well Connected at Home, Young Malaysian Has an Appetite for New York
item.description: Jho Low has partied with stars and orchestrated multimillion-dollar deals, including transactions involving the stepson of Malaysia’s prime minister.
item.dc:creator: By LOUISE STORY and STEPHANIE SAUL
item.media:description: Jho Low, left, a Malaysian investor, with Paris Hilton at a nightclub in St.-Tropez, France, in 2010.

item.title: Towers of Secrecy: Urusan pelaburan di AS oleh seorang rakyat Malaysia yang rapat dengan ramai orang ternama menimbulkan tanda tanya
item.description: Jho Low pernah berparti bersama selebriti-selebriti terkenal, dan juga telah melakukan beberapa urus janji hartanah bernilai jutaan dollar yang turut membabitkan anak tiri kepada perdana menteri Malaysia.
item.media:description: Time Warner Center, dua menara bercahaya di sebelah kanan, menjadi tumpuan utama banyak urusan pelaburan asing dalam industri hartanah mewah yang dirahsiakan di Manhattan.

item.title: Memo From Munich: Crisis in Ukraine Underscores Opposing Lessons of Cold War
item.description: Officials from Germany and the United States drew very different lessons from the West’s 20th-century showdown with the Soviet Union, as they clashed over whether to arm Kiev’s troops.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Prime Minister Tony Abbott Keeps Hold of Job in Party Vote in Australia
item.description: Mr. Abbott fought off a challenge to his leadership after lawmakers from his conservative Liberal Party voted against a motion to declare the party’s top positions vacant.
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Police Force in Afghanistan Is Studied for Ties to Taliban
item.description: A Taliban commander described how police officers helped Taliban fighters, sometimes selling them ammunition, other times tipping them off to impending police operations, a member of Afghanistan’s Parliament said.
item.dc:creator: By JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN

item.title: Soccer Stadium Stampede Kills at Least 25 in Egypt
item.description: Fans said that the police set off the stampede by firing tear gas into a crowd of thousands trying to enter the stadium without tickets.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and MERNA THOMAS
item.media:description: A police car was set on fire during the confrontation between officers and soccer fans at the gates of a stadium outside Cairo.

item.title: Deadline Nearing, Iran Presses for Progress in Nuclear Talks
item.description: Iran’s foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, spoke Sunday at a security conference in Munich, where Germany also announced a planned summit meeting on Wednesday to try to resolve the Ukraine crisis.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: “We need to seize this opportunity,” Iran’s foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, said Sunday in Munich.

item.title: Supermarket Chain Denies Venezuela's Charges of Food Hoarding
item.description: The head of a supermarket chain taken over by the government rejected claims that the company was hoarding foodstuffs to destabilize the economy.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: Egypt Moves Toward Retrial for 2 Jailed Al Jazeera Journalists
item.description: After the release of an Australian colleague, the two remained imprisoned on charges relating to their journalism.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: As Technology Entrepreneurs Multiply in Vietnam, So Do Regulations
item.description: A growing list of government rules dictates how technology businesses must be run, including what they can do with their content.
item.dc:creator: By MIKE IVES

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Don't Arm Ukraine
item.description: For America to supply Kiev with weapons would only make Russia a more reckless adversary.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN J. MEARSHEIMER
item.media:description: Ukrainian Army soldiers at a weapons training exercise in western Ukraine last week.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Bangladesh's Hope for Justice
item.description: Amid all the political strife, one bright spot is a reforming leader of the Supreme Court.
item.dc:creator: By TAHMIMA ANAM

item.title: Prime Minister of Greece Will Not Prolong Bailout
item.description: In an address to Parliament on Sunday, Alexis Tsipras promised to carry out his campaign pledges to roll back austerity.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: Tycoon and Mubarak Ally Seeks Return to Parliament
item.description: Ahmed Ezz, who once steered the ruling party for President Hosni Mubarak, was long reviled in Egypt as the personification of crony capitalism.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Desperation and Destruction in Contested Ukraine City
item.description: Debaltseve, a crucial rail junction, has become the main focus of combat in eastern Ukraine, and has been battered by shelling from rebel forces eager to control it.
item.dc:creator: By RICK LYMAN

item.title: Global Health: In Treating Ebola, Even Using a Stethoscope Becomes a Challenge
item.description: While the stethoscope remains useful, the dangers of Ebola have forced doctors to adapt their methods for obtaining the information it provides.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.media:credit: Eric Francis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Phillip Smith demonstrated how to use an electronic stethoscope while at an infectious disease unit in Nebraska.

item.title: North Korea Tests Five Missiles
item.description: The launchings, reported by South Korea, came a day after the North said that its leader had witnessed the test-firing of a new antiship missile.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Kcna, via Kns/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An image released by North Korea over the weekend, in what state news media said was the test-firing of a new antiship missile.

item.title: Greek Austerity Spawns Fakery: Playing Nurse
item.description: When patients go to a hospital in Greece, they often must hire their own nurses just to receive basic care, and many of those nurses are untrained and illegal.
item.dc:creator: By DANNY HAKIM
item.media:credit: Eirini Vourloumis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anastasios Grigoropoulos, chief of Evangelismos Hospital, said, “We see more and more illegal nurses.”

item.title: Saudis Unswayed by Houthi Rebels’ Overture in Yemen
item.description: Rebel leaders announced on Saturday that they had appointed four key ministers from the Yemeni government they had overthrown, but Saudi Arabia and its allies denounced the plan.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and SHUAIB ALMOSAWA
